dublinCore.title: Brownian Motion Simulation
creator: Claude Code
Dan McCreary
subject: Physics
Chemistry
Kinetic Molecular Theory
dublinCore.description: Interactive simulation demonstrating Brownian motion of gas molecules in a chamber with controls for temperature, molecule count, and chamber size. Displays real-time collision frequency.

educational.topic: Kinetic Molecular Theory, Gas Laws, Thermodynamics
learningObjectives: Describe the relationship between temperature and molecular motion
Explain how molecular density affects collision frequency
Connect microscopic molecular behavior to macroscopic properties
Understand the random nature of molecular motion in gases
Apply kinetic molecular theory to explain gas behavior
educational.prerequisites: Basic understanding of matter, atoms, and molecules

controls.name: temperatureSlider
controls.label: Temperature
controls.description: Controls the speed/kinetic energy of molecules

controls.name: moleculesSlider
controls.label: Molecules
controls.description: Number of gas molecules in the chamber

controls.name: areaSlider
controls.label: Chamber Size
controls.description: Size of the rectangular chamber (affects density)

displays.name: collisionsPerSecond
displays.description: Real-time count of molecular collisions per second

assumptions: Molecules are represented as circles with uniform radius
All collisions are perfectly elastic (no energy loss)
limitations: Does not account for molecular rotation or vibration

commonMisconceptions: Molecules slow down over time (they maintain constant average speed)
Molecules move in organized patterns (motion is random)
Temperature is the same as heat (temperature relates to average KE)
assessmentOpportunities: Explain pressure in terms of molecular collisions
Analyze effects of density on gas behavior
